1.1Â BudgetingÂ andÂ PublicÂ SectorÂ PerformanceÂ PerformanceÂ informationÂ canÂ contributeÂ toÂ goodÂ publicÂ sectorÂ budgetingÂ inÂ threeÂ keyÂ ways.Â
First,Â itÂ helpsÂ improveÂ expenditureÂ prioritization.Â Â ExpenditureÂ prioritizationÂ meansÂ thatÂ governmentÂ resourcesÂ areÂ allocatedÂ toÂ theÂ programsÂ whichÂ deliverÂ theÂ greatestÂ benefitsÂ toÂ theÂ communityÂ givenÂ theÂ moneyÂ spent.Â ThisÂ isÂ whatÂ economistsÂ referÂ toÂ asÂ "allocativeÂ efficiency."Â ForÂ expenditureÂ prioritization,Â itÂ isÂ theÂ relevanceÂ andÂ effectivenessÂ ofÂ programsÂ thatÂ areÂ important.Â RelevanceÂ refersÂ toÂ theÂ importanceÂ toÂ theÂ communityÂ ofÂ theÂ outcomesÂ theÂ programÂ aimsÂ toÂ achieveÂ â€“Â forÂ example,Â theÂ extentÂ toÂ whichÂ toÂ aÂ programÂ addressesÂ aÂ majorÂ problemÂ orÂ seeksÂ toÂ achieveÂ outcomesÂ thatÂ citizensÂ valueÂ highly.1Â Effectiveness,Â inÂ contrast,Â meansÂ thatÂ programsÂ actuallyÂ achieveÂ theirÂ intendedÂ outcomesÂ â€“Â forÂ example,Â anÂ AIDSÂ preventionÂ programÂ actuallyÂ reducesÂ theÂ rateÂ ofÂ AIDSÂ infection.Â ExpenditureÂ prioritization,Â then,Â willÂ beÂ improvedÂ toÂ theÂ extentÂ thatÂ budgetÂ decisionÂ makersÂ haveÂ goodÂ informationÂ onÂ theÂ relevanceÂ andÂ effectivenessÂ ofÂ expenditureÂ andÂ useÂ thisÂ informationÂ inÂ decidingÂ whichÂ programsÂ andÂ projectsÂ toÂ fund.Â
Second,Â itÂ putsÂ increasedÂ pressureÂ onÂ ministriesÂ toÂ improveÂ theÂ effectivenessÂ ofÂ theirÂ programs.Â IfÂ spendingÂ ministriesÂ knowÂ thatÂ theÂ MinistryÂ ofÂ FinanceÂ andÂ otherÂ budgetÂ decisionÂ makersÂ haveÂ goodÂ informationÂ aboutÂ theÂ effectivenessÂ ofÂ theirÂ programsÂ andÂ thatÂ theyÂ takeÂ programÂ effectivenessÂ intoÂ accountÂ whenÂ decidingÂ howÂ muchÂ fundingÂ toÂ provideÂ inÂ theÂ budget,Â theyÂ willÂ feelÂ greaterÂ pressureÂ toÂ improveÂ theÂ effectivenessÂ ofÂ theirÂ programsÂ toÂ protectÂ theirÂ budgetÂ allocations.Â Â
Third,Â theÂ availabilityÂ andÂ useÂ ofÂ performanceÂ informationÂ canÂ helpÂ ensureÂ thatÂ theÂ budgetÂ promotesÂ efficiency.Â EfficiencyÂ meansÂ thatÂ governmentÂ servicesÂ areÂ deliveredÂ atÂ theÂ lowestÂ possibleÂ cost,Â consistentÂ withÂ theÂ maintenanceÂ ofÂ quality.2Â PromotingÂ efficiencyÂ viaÂ theÂ budgetÂ meansÂ avoidingÂ fundingÂ ministriesÂ atÂ levelsÂ thatÂ permitÂ themÂ toÂ operateÂ wastefullyÂ (forÂ example,Â atÂ lowÂ levelsÂ ofÂ laborÂ productivityÂ orÂ withÂ inappropriateÂ businessÂ processes,Â whichÂ raiseÂ costsÂ unnecessarily).Â MoreÂ precisely,Â budgetingÂ promotesÂ efficiencyÂ whenÂ budgetÂ decisionÂ makersÂ seekÂ toÂ baseÂ theÂ levelÂ ofÂ programÂ fundingÂ onÂ theÂ efficientÂ costÂ ofÂ serviceÂ provisionÂ whileÂ simultaneouslyÂ holdingÂ ministriesÂ accountableÂ forÂ maintainingÂ theÂ levelÂ andÂ qualityÂ ofÂ servicesÂ providedÂ toÂ theÂ public.Â

ToÂ beÂ ableÂ toÂ fundÂ importantÂ newÂ spendingÂ prioritiesÂ increasinglyÂ requiresÂ cuts.Â "SpendingÂ reviews"Â toÂ areÂ increasinglyÂ anÂ integralÂ partÂ ofÂ budgetÂ preparation,Â andÂ itÂ isÂ widelyÂ recognizedÂ thatÂ evaluationÂ hasÂ aÂ potentiallyÂ veryÂ importantÂ roleÂ toÂ playÂ inÂ facilitatingÂ aÂ moreÂ informedÂ typeÂ ofÂ spendingÂ review.Â Specifically,Â evaluationÂ canÂ beÂ ofÂ greatÂ assistanceÂ inÂ helpingÂ spendingÂ reviewÂ toÂ identifyÂ programsÂ whichÂ areÂ irredeemablyÂ ineffectiveÂ orÂ whichÂ doÂ notÂ provideÂ resultsÂ sufficientÂ toÂ justifyÂ theÂ resourcesÂ theyÂ absorb.Â
ToÂ bringÂ evaluationÂ andÂ budgetingÂ togetherÂ requiresÂ thatÂ theyÂ bothÂ change.Â InsofarÂ asÂ itÂ isÂ intendedÂ toÂ supportÂ betterÂ budgeting,Â evaluationÂ mustÂ beÂ tailoredÂ toÂ thatÂ purposeÂ throughÂ theÂ appropriateÂ selectionÂ ofÂ evaluationÂ topicsÂ (thatÂ is,Â focusingÂ onÂ areasÂ ofÂ potentialÂ budgetaryÂ savings).Â TheÂ typeÂ ofÂ evaluationÂ carriedÂ outÂ alsoÂ needsÂ toÂ reflectÂ budgetaryÂ concerns,Â particularlyÂ byÂ helpingÂ identifyÂ savingsÂ optionsÂ ratherÂ thanÂ focusingÂ onÂ managementÂ andÂ policyÂ improvements,Â whichÂ hasÂ tendedÂ toÂ dominateÂ evaluationÂ inÂ theÂ past.Â ThisÂ meansÂ moreÂ focusÂ onÂ outcomeÂ evaluationÂ andÂ programÂ logicÂ analysis.Â Â
TheÂ needÂ toÂ ensureÂ thatÂ evaluationsÂ areÂ tailoredÂ toÂ theÂ needsÂ ofÂ budgetÂ decisionÂ makersÂ alsoÂ raisesÂ theÂ questionÂ asÂ toÂ whetherÂ governmentâ€wideÂ evaluationÂ systemsÂ shouldÂ beÂ expectedÂ toÂ deliverÂ theÂ typesÂ ofÂ

doc.abstracts: This paper discusses how evaluation is an essential tool for good budgeting and a core element of any well-designed government wide performance budgeting system. It is organized into 5 sections: (1) Evaluation and performance budgeting- the principle outlines the role which evaluation should, in principle, play in supporting good budgeting. It identifies the key ways performance information in general supports budgeting and then outlines the way performance budgeting seeks to structure the contribution of performance information to budgeting. The section concludes by discussing the nature and role of evaluation as a key component of the performance information base for budgeting. (2) Evaluation and performance budgeting in practice reviews the actual relationship between evaluation and performance budgeting by looking at the experiences of countries that have made substantial efforts to implement both. (3) Recent Efforts to Connect Evaluation and Budgeting discusses the global financial crisis, renewed interest in the role of evaluation as a budgetary tool is increasingly apparent among OECD countries, with countries such as the United States and the Netherlands making moves in this direction. (4) How to Better Connect Evaluation and Budgeting requires two things. First, evaluation needs to be made more useful for budgeting. Second, the budget process needs to focus more on expenditure prioritization and performance. (5) Conclusions.
